item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Rebels Kill at Least 12 in Attack on Convoy
item.description: At least 12 people were killed and more than 27 were wounded when suicide bombers attacked a convoy carrying African Union troops and Somali officials, officials and witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMED IBRAHIM

item.title: World Briefing: Chile: Bombing in Santiago Wounds at Least 14 People
item.description: A bomb exploded in a subway station in Santiago, the capital, on Monday, wounding at least 14 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Peru: 4 Opponents of Illegal Logging Are Found Dead
item.description: An outspoken Peruvian opponent of illegal logging and three other native Ash√°ninka community leaders were brutally slain in a remote region bordering Brazil, tribal authorities said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: As Sweden Nears Vote, Center-Right Is Trailing
item.description: Sweden is now sharply divided over big, emotive issues like immigration and the future of the welfare state.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CROUCH
item.media:description: The Swedish flag in front of a house southwest of Stockholm. The country has maintained an open-door policy to refugees for decades, but has struggled to integrate many of the new arrivals.

item.title: White House Memo: A President Whose Assurances Have Come Back to Haunt Him
item.description: President Obama has been undermined by his own statements, like the one where he said Iraq was ‚Äúsovereign, stable and self-reliant‚Äù with ‚Äúa representative government.‚Äù
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: U.S. Delegation Is to Visit Moscow to Review Claims of a Missile Violation
item.description: United States officials believe Russia may have tested a ground-launched cruise missile in violation of the 1987 Soviet-American treaty.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/RIA Novosti, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, visiting a youth camp, said, ‚ÄúI want to remind you that Russia is one of the most powerful nuclear nations.‚Äù

item.title: As Obama Makes Case, Congress Is Divided on Campaign Against Militants
item.description: President Obama on Tuesday will begin laying out his case for an expanded military campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria when he faces congressional leaders.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN, MARK LANDLER and JEREMY W. PETERS
item.media:description: Representative Jack Kingston of Georgia said Congress should hold an authorization vote.

item.title: Zumpango Journal: They Built It. People Came. Now They Go.
item.description: A government program to solve Mexico‚Äôs chronic housing shortage produced huge developments without jobs or supporting services, forcing thousands of new owners to abandon their homes.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of homes have been abandoned in La Trinidad, an 8,000-unit development in Zumpango, Mexico.

item.title: Lawmakers Approve Cabinet in Iraq, but 2 Posts Are Empty
item.description: Iraqi legislators approved a new power-sharing government led by the Shiite prime minister, Haider al-Abadi, but they left the two most divisive security posts unfilled, potentially extending a contentious debate.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Members of the Iraqi Parliament approved a new government in Baghdad on Monday.

item.title: Google Is Target of European Backlash on U.S. Tech Dominance
item.description: Regulators want Google to change its algorithm. If Google doesn‚Äôt comply, the settlement it reached with Europe this year may be voided and it will face antitrust charges.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: Google‚Äôs Street View service surveying Amsterdam; some European countries have fined it.

item.title: Ebola Cases Reported Up Sharply in Liberia
item.description: The World Health Organization said the numbers of new patients in Liberia pointed to ‚Äúa large but previously invisible caseload.‚Äù
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burial team in Monrovia, Liberia, on Saturday collected the body of a man believed to have died from Ebola. Their workload has grown quickly in recent weeks.

item.title: Brushing Off Threats, E.U. Votes to Toughen Its Sanctions on Russia
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine visited the port city of Mariupol during a fragile truce with pro-Russian separatists and pledged not to give up any land.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine spoke with workers in the port city of Mariupol on Monday.

item.title: Coalition Urges Nations to Decriminalize Drugs and Drug Use
item.description: The Global Commission on Drug Policy, a group made up of former presidents and politicians, is calling for less emphasis on punishment and more on treatment while still targeting criminal drug gang operations.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Another Royal Baby Is Expected for an Uneasy Kingdom
item.description: The announcement of the pregnancy set off speculation about whether it would influence a secession vote in Scotland.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Prince William and Catherine, the Duchess of Cambridge, with Prince George at the Natural History Museum in London in July.

item.title: India and Pakistan Strain as Flooding Kills Hundreds
item.description: Thousands more have been displaced in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir and in neighboring Pakistan. Rescue efforts were hampered Monday by high waters.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: A damaged bridge across the Tawi River in the region of Jammu, where at least 140 people died in severe flooding.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: For Australia, a Celebration of China in Theme Park Form
item.description: Developers are planning a $500 million, 39-acre Chinese culture theme park north of Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Ukraine Palace Is Still Emblem of Dysfunction
item.description: More than six months after protesters drove Viktor F. Yanukovych from power, his lavish estate displays how difficult it is to bring about a real break with Ukraine‚Äôs past.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: It costs visitors about a dollar to enter the estate of former President Viktor F. Yanukovych, with guided tours of its villa on offer for $15.

item.title: Iraqi Lawmakers Approve Cabinet, as New Premier Pledges an Inclusive Government
item.description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi leads a government with two security posts not filled, which could lead to a political debate.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and AZAM AHMED

item.title: Iran‚Äôs Top Leader Undergoes Prostate Surgery
item.description: There was no word on whether the leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, 75, has prostate cancer, but doctors called the operation a success.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei's website posted photographs of a hospital visit on Monday by President Hassan Rouhani.

item.title: Turkey Is Courted by U.S. to Help Fight ISIS
item.description: Chuck Hagel, the defense secretary, met with Turkish officials on Monday to persuade them to join the coalition being formed to fight the Sunni militant group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, left, met Monday with Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president of Turkey, to gauge Turkey's willingness to participate in an American-led coalition against the militant group ISIS, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Zalmay Khalilzad Is Suspected of Tax Evasion and Money Laundering
item.description: Zalmay Khalilzad, a former American ambassador, is suspected of tax evasion and money laundering, and his wife‚Äôs accounts in Austria have been frozen, a magazine reported.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Brendan Smialowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad, center, in 2008. Viennese officials confirmed that accounts owned by his wife, Cheryl Benard, a dual American and Austrian citizen, had been frozen.

item.title: World Briefing: Germany Arrests 3 on Charges of Joining Somali Militants
item.description: The three men were arrested upon their return to Germany after receiving training and then fighting alongside militants from the group known as the Shabab.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Afghan Candidate Vows to Reject Disputed Vote
item.description: Abdullah Abdullah said he would not recognize any government formed on the basis of an audit, nearly complete, of the votes in his runoff election against Ashraf Ghani.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah, center, insisted again in Kabul on Monday that he had won the disputed vote.

item.title: Iran‚Äôs Top Leader Undergoes Prostate Surgery
item.description: There was no word on whether the leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, 75, has prostate cancer, but doctors called the operation a success.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Letter From Europe: Raw Politics on French Bookshelves
item.description: Two books are making waves because of their uncanny timing ‚Äî one by President Fran√ßois Hollande‚Äôs former partner and another about a member of Mr. Hollande‚Äôs cabinet who has just left.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: In "Merci Pour Ce Moment" ("Thank You For This Moment"), Val√©rie Trierweiler, President Fran√ßois Hollande's former companion, tells of how she tried to overdose on sleeping pills after learning that Mr. Hollande was cheating on her.
